summary:
Senior Geophysicist / Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager, Specialised in high-resolution 2D/3D offshore seismic.

Roles as Project Manager, Client Representative, Project Leader, Party Chief and Lead Geophysicist, supervising data acquisition, processing, interpretation and reporting for drilling hazard site surveys, geophysical, seismic and UXO surveys, windmill parks, geotechnical investigations, sediment prospecting surveys, pipeline- and cable routes, environmental surveys and construction projects.

Experienced with project proposals, ITT preparation, bidding, technical and commercial contract evaluation.

Design and drafting of geophysical and geotechnical equipment. Manufacturing engineer for such equipment, experienced with maintenance and repairs, mobilising and testing.

In the 'Projects' section below I highlighted some projects that I consider out of the ordinary, or particularly enjoyed working on. Please feel free to contact me if you would like to know more about these or other projects that are listed in my downloadable CV.

projects:
[{'title': 'Turkstream', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Survey Expert for the Turkstream pipeline project from Russia to Turkey crossing the full length and depth of the Black Sea. Involved in all aspects of the preparation and execution of survey (FEED, combined reconnaissance and detailed) and construction work, offshore, nearshore and onshore, geophysical and geotechnical. This project is in many aspects the most complex and biggest offshore construction ever attempted.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': 'Kashagan transition zone pipeline route survey', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2005}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2005}}, 'description': 'On-site Project Manager for the Kashagan pipeline route survey in shallow water and transition zone, 70 km, NE Caspian. The project included 2 offshore vessels, a nearshore vessel, amphibians, swamp boats, hovercrafts, jack-up rigs, a fleet of 4x4 vehicles etc., including onshore geophysics. Total crew over 200 persons. Environmental constraints required unconventional solutions. For example, a small tug boat with barge was organised to come down the Ural river from Atyrau to collect grey water on a weekly basis, to prevent the offshore vessels to have to sail to Bautino for discharge, 36 hrs and back.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': 'Integrating geology with architecture', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 1990}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 1990}}, 'description': 'During fieldwork in Calabria, southern Italy, it was recognised that recent geological history is actually documented better in old buildings than in rocky outcrops. Calabria is tectonically still very active today and this is reflected in deviations from verticality in the walls of historic buildings, but also in e.g. preferential crack orientations. Research was combined with archaeologists from Turin University to identify non-restored parts of old buildings, and with restoration engineers to better understand stresses and crack development in walls.
This principle was later used by Utrecht University to extensively map Greek temple remains and document recent tectonic movements in Greece.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': '3D High-resolution site survey with integrated undershoot', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'One of the first 3D High-resolution site surveys on the North Sea to image a 3x3km shallow area in detail, with integrated undershooting of an existing platform. Results are of very high quality.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': 'Deep water drilling hazard site surveys in Angola', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': "Geohazard analysis of tens of (drilling) sites in water depths of over one km. Special focus on gas hydrate phenomena on the seabed like 'hydrate pingoes' and Bottom Simulating Reflectors (BSR), or the absence thereof. Publication in preparation.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': 'Innovative routines for acquisition and processing of ultra-high resolution seismic', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2010}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'description': "Development of innovative routines to accurately acquire and process ultra-high resolution multi-channel data, in 2D and 3D.
Ultra-high resolution (UHR) seismic, when correctly recorded with a single-channel streamer, can have a resolution in the decimetre realm. In theory, the same resolution could be achieved with multi-channel systems, also in 3D. However, variations in acquisition geometry and particularly swell (variation in water- and streamer depth) are easily in the order of magnitude of the resolution, and thus have the capability of degrading the data, especially when stacked.
A series of routines has been developed to respect the resolution of UHR data during acquisition and processing, with very good results, significantly enhancing the quality of final results when compared with traditional methods. Note that 'traditional' is relative as UHR multi-channel data acquisition is a recent development.
As a side effect, applying these routines, data acquired in weather conditions that are normally considered way beyond suitable, can still result in acceptable, fit-for-purpose records.
See a few slides in attached presentation for an example.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': 'High-frequent vibro-corers', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2003}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2005}}, 'description': 'Geo-Resources Instruments developed high-frequent, modular vibro-corers. The barrel length can be adjusted from 3 to 9 meters, and elements are interchangeable with piston- and gravity cores.
The principle is that the vibro-corer works at or near the eigenfequency (natural or resonance frequency), a condition normally to be avoided in engineering, but in this case causing the corer head to vibrate violently at exactly the operating frequency.
This results in a very powerful corer that penetrates in very short time, recovering relatively undisturbed samples.  Other vibro-corers on the market do not operate at this frequency and are far less effective, even when much heavier.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}, {'title': 'Negative polarity high-voltage power supplies', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2000}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2003}}, 'description': "Geo-Resources Instruments developed high-voltage power supplies with negative polarity power output for high-quality sparker sources. Originally branded as the Positive Earth Principle (PEP) and patented.
Amongst other effects, the negative polarity creates a very clean and short spark with no reverberations and no noticeable tip consumption, resulting in a stable, absolutely constant pulse for thousands of acquisition line kilometres without maintenance. Tip consumption and the resulting change in signature was a problem with traditional sparkers, not to mention acquisition time lost due to maintenance. These issues are eliminated entirely. Note that a negative polarity is not the same as switching the live and earth cable on the power supply.
Competitors initially tried to ignore the innovation stating 'no positive effect is expected from negative polarity power supplies' but now have power supplies based on the same principle in their product range.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Rombout', 'last_name': 'Knook', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geohazard Specialist / Project Manager / Geophysicist'}]}]
